summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from October to November 2021 between prosecutors and defense attorneys regarding scheduling meetings and witness preparation for the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330). The emails discuss coordinating a call with a JPMorgan witness, providing a trial subpoena, and scheduling around jury selection.

persons.name: Allison Stoddart
persons.context: Attorney from WilmerHale representing or involved in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, coordinating scheduling and witness matters with the prosecution.

persons.name: Anjan Sahni
persons.context: Prosecutor from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York involved in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, corresponding about trial witness preparation.

persons.name: Pat McHugh
persons.context: Individual mentioned as part of a team for whom a call is being scheduled; likely a colleague of the email sender.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced throughout the emails (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330).

connections.description: Defense attorney and prosecutor corresponding about scheduling and trial preparation matters in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

events.title: Jury Selection for Maxwell Trial
events.description: Jury selection is scheduled and impacting the availability of legal teams for meetings.

events.title: Trial Witness Preparation
events.description: Ongoing coordination between prosecution and defense to identify and prepare a witness from JPMorgan for trial, including drafting a subpoena.

locations: 7 World Trade Center, 250 Greenwich Street, New York, NY 10007
One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The emails show active coordination between the prosecution (AUSA Anjan Sahni) and defense (attorney Allison Stoddart) in the lead-up to Ghislaine Maxwell's trial in late 2021.
Jury selection for the Maxwell trial was underway in November 2021, creating scheduling challenges for the legal teams.
The prosecution was working with JPMorgan to identify a trial witness and provided a draft subpoena to the defense.
The correspondence indicates the use of external email senders, highlighting communication between the U.S. Attorney's Office and private defense counsel.
